pullRequest.body:
Define `edist` as the extended distance between two vertices of a simple graph, belonging to `ENat`, and rewrite `dist` as the coercion of `edist` to `Nat` using `toNat`. Rewrite the API to meet these new definitions.

Co-authored-by: Bhavik Mehta <bhavikmehta8@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks, and is labeled with `awaiting-review`.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

#### Declarations diff

Nice work!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10124223176/job/27998338010)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10124223176/job/27998337708)
Thanks! Overall it looks good. Some suggestions below:

The dist theorems don't seem to follow the mathlib naming convention. Would you mind updating them and these edist theorems? I'm thinking this could be `Reachable.exists_walk_length_eq_edist` (and similar for `Connected` and the pre-existing dist versions).

Thank you.  I've updated the naming of the lemmas that don't follow the naming convention, but I find naming lemmas confusing as there are lots of exceptions and subtleties.  Please let me know if the names are good now or if any needs changing.
Sorry, I meant to say *just* these four theorems needed changing. Could you revert your last commit please?
Sure!

I think it would be good to include
```lean
theorem edist_eq_sInf : G.edist u v = sInf (Set.range fun w : G.Walk u v ↦ (w.length : ℕ∞)) := rfl
```
so that it's possible to rewrite without trying to get things to unfold in the right way.

Now that we're using ENat, we don't need to reason by cases. First, we should have this theorem in Connectivity:
```lean
theorem Walk.reverse_surjective : Function.Surjective (Walk.reverse : G.Walk u v → _) :=
  Function.RightInverse.surjective Walk.reverse_reverse
```
And then we can do some rewriting:
```suggestion
theorem edist_comm : G.edist u v = G.edist v u := by
  rw [edist_eq_sInf, ← Set.image_univ, ← Set.image_univ_of_surjective Walk.reverse_surjective,
    ← Set.image_comp, Set.image_univ, Function.comp_def]
  simp_rw [Walk.length_reverse, ← edist_eq_sInf]
```
I feel like there's a missing iInf reindexing lemma (do you know @b-mehta ?)

Now that we're using ENat, we don't need to reason by cases. First, we should have this theorem in Connectivity:
```lean
lemma Walk.reverse_surjective : Function.Surjective (Walk.reverse : G.Walk u v → _) :=
  Function.RightInverse.surjective Walk.reverse_reverse
```
And then we can do some rewriting:
```suggestion
theorem edist_comm : G.edist u v = G.edist v u := by
  rw [edist_eq_sInf, ← Set.image_univ, ← Set.image_univ_of_surjective Walk.reverse_surjective,
    ← Set.image_comp, Set.image_univ, Function.comp_def]
  simp_rw [Walk.length_reverse, ← edist_eq_sInf]
```
I feel like there's a missing iInf reindexing lemma. I'd rather be able to say "reindex using this surjective function". (Do you know @b-mehta ?)
Hmm not sure, although if we have bijectivity it could be even easier. Will think about this.

Changes:
* Use `obtain` instead of `let` since it's a proof (`have` would work too). There's no difference in this case, but `let` signals "I care about the definition"
* Rather than define a sub-lemma, it's possible to use `simp` (or `decide`) to handle the neq. This is a slight abuse of `rw`'s ability to unify metavariables, and more principled would be `obtain ⟨w, hw⟩ := exists_walk_of_edist_ne_top (by rw [h]; simp : G.edist u v ≠ ⊤)`.
* `le_antisymm` instead of `ge_antisymm` since the operands are in terms of le, for clarity.

```suggestion
theorem edist_eq_one_iff_adj : G.edist u v = 1 ↔ G.Adj u v := by
  refine ⟨fun h ↦ ?_, fun h ↦ ?_⟩
  · obtain ⟨w, hw⟩ := exists_walk_of_edist_ne_top <| by rw [h]; simp
    rw [h, Nat.cast_eq_one] at hw
    exact w.adj_of_length_eq_one hw
  · exact le_antisymm (edist_le h.toWalk) (ENat.one_le_iff_pos.mpr <| pos_edist_of_ne h.ne)
```

We can delete `dist_comm_aux` and make use of `edist_comm`:
```suggestion
theorem dist_comm : G.dist u v = G.dist v u := by
  by_cases h : G.Reachable u v
  · rw [dist, edist_comm, ← dist]
  · have h' : ¬G.Reachable v u := fun h' => absurd h'.symm h
    simp [h, h', dist_eq_zero_of_not_reachable]
```

Again, let's make use of the edist lemma:
```suggestion
theorem dist_eq_one_iff_adj : G.dist u v = 1 ↔ G.Adj u v := by
  rw [dist, ENat.toNat_eq_iff, ENat.coe_one, edist_eq_one_iff_adj]
  decide
```
I think Involutive might be the correct thing to have here, maybe Bijective / Surj / Inj could be given from that but imo Involutive is enough

I'm facing an issue here: `Function.Involutive` expects the function to have the same domain type and range type, but for reverse, the domain is of type `G.Walk u v` while its range is of type `G.Walk v u`.

Oh yeah, that's a fundamental issue. How about for now we settle for `reverse_surjective` for now? If you want you can also throw in `reverse_injective` and `reverse_bijective`.

There's a way to state that it's involutive, but what comes to mind involves sigma types and isn't very nice:
```
theorem Walk.reverse_involutive :
    Function.Involutive
      (Sigma.map Prod.swap (fun _ => Walk.reverse) : (p : V × V) × G.Walk p.1 p.2 → (p : V × V) × G.Walk p.1 p.2) := by
  intro ⟨u, v⟩
  simp [Sigma.map]
```
Oh right, good point! Yeah don't do involutive
I think a simp lemma saying `⨅ i, (f i : ℕ∞) = ⊤` in the case that iota is empty would be sensible, and also simplify this bit of the proof
Maybe an alias for Walk.edist_le could be nice

Probably like this:
```
protected alias Walk.edist_le := edist_le
```

alias `Ne.edist_pos` maybe?

also I think this should be edist_pos_of_ne
Should I also change the `dist` versions of the lemmas and alias them too?

Are you sure about this alias Bhavik? This is putting a graph-specific theorem in the global Ne namespace. We could have `Ne.simpleGraph_walk_edist_pos` or something like that, but otherwise I'd suggest not having such an alias.
Oh true, `Ne.edist_pos` is probably too non-specific to be global
I wouldn't use `Reachable.` here, since dot notation won't apply. `reachable_of_edist_ne_top` would be better
Might be a good simp lemma
you can actually do this whole proof with just `rw [dist, dist, edist_comm]`

```
lemma exists_walk_of_edist_eq_coe {k : ℕ} (h : G.edist u v = k) :
    ∃ p : G.Walk u v, p.length = k :=
  have : G.edist u v ≠ ⊤ := by rw [h]; exact ENat.coe_ne_top _
  have ⟨p, hp⟩ := exists_walk_of_edist_ne_top this
  ⟨p, Nat.cast_injective (hp.trans h)⟩
```
this seems helpful, I think.

Also a statement that edist isn't top iff the vertices are reachable (as an iff) would be good

This doesn't need connectedness since we're using edist!
```
protected theorem edist_triangle : G.edist u w ≤ G.edist u v + G.edist v w := by
  rcases eq_or_ne (G.edist u v) ⊤ with huv | huv
  case inl => simp [huv]
  case inr =>
    rcases eq_or_ne (G.edist v w) ⊤ with hvw | hvw
    case inl => simp [hvw]
    case inr =>
      obtain ⟨p, hp⟩ := exists_walk_of_edist_ne_top huv
      obtain ⟨q, hq⟩ := exists_walk_of_edist_ne_top hvw
      rw [←hp, ←hq, ←Nat.cast_add, ←Walk.length_append]
      exact edist_le _
 ```

It's probably not worth developing all this theory, but it occurred to me that we could pull back infinity to Walk to have "extended walks", along with the "does not exist" walk. Then `edist_triangle` could be proved without any cases, because it's already been done in `EWalk.length_append`.
```lean
def EWalk (u v : V) := Option (G.Walk u v)

def EWalk.length : G.EWalk u v → ℕ∞ := Option.map Walk.length

def EWalk.append (p : G.EWalk u v) (q : G.EWalk v w) : G.EWalk u w :=
  Walk.append <$> p <*> q

def EWalk.length_append {p : G.EWalk u v} {q : G.EWalk v w} :
    (p.append q).length = p.length + q.length := by
  cases p <;> cases q <;> simp [EWalk.append, EWalk.length] <;> rfl

theorem exists_ewalk_length_eq_edist :
    ∃ p : G.EWalk u v, p.length = G.edist u v := by
  sorry
```

It is a great idea! I'll keep it in mind to potentially work on.
I think it would be nicer to move `Walk`s from `Connectivity.lean` into their own file (in the `Connectivity` folder) before attempting that, what do you think?
I think that change does sound valuable - Reachable and Connected can be in Connectivity.lean; Walks and Paths can be in Walk.lean
#15171 does this.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Combinatorics/SimpleGraph): define `edist` and rewrite `dist`
